comment: This is  strong, very strong. It’s decent, but not my favorite OF product. Will strive for 1910 over this.
Great nose!  Slightly sweet minimal burn.  Viscous body.  Great finish.  Taste reminded of chocolate covered cherries.
Smoky and spicy.  Sweet with vanilla tastes
It starts out hot with a lot of oak, settles into a caramel bomb and then finishes with a bit of peanut and more oak. my favorite every day pour.
easy, smooth, ful bodied, spice on the tongue, easy finish
Good, but I had a hard time finding a sweet spot in terms of adding water.  Tastes like a stronger version of the 1897, but harsher even after water.
Same mash bill as Woodford but a lot more kick!
Sweet vanilla and caramel give-way to a spicy cinnamon and clove bite that wraps your tongue and lasts for a long, smooth, hot finish.

Nose: dry with noticeable ethanol but quickly turns to biscuity & hearty grain bread
Palate: initial heat up front leads to a mixing of both nutty & spicy w/burnt sugar notes. 
Finish: moderately long, heat is manageable & spice is nice. 
115proof deceives - approachable & pleasant but will creep up on you.

Wow! Talk about bang for your buck. This bourbon hits you hard but not overall harsh that you can’t enjoy. I usually enjoy my bourbons neat but I had to add an ice cube to help open this one up a bit for myself.
Way to go Alex Morgan and the US on the hat trick and win!
better than an 85 rating.  legit bourbon.

—2nd go round & this time with food-
Nose: pancakes w/syrup, almond cookies, light smoke & toasted marshmallow
Palate: thin body, cinnamon, Oak & light blood orange 
Finish: has heat but dissipates quickly

This bourbon is smooth. Heavy on vanilla, oak and heat. I was honestly surprised to find that it’s 57.5% because of how smooth it is. Others have said they found cherry and chocolate, but I got very light chocolate and no cherry.
awesome once ice melts.  very good product, a little heat to begin with, but very enjoyable in the finish..

This wasn't a bad taste but neither was it something I'd go back to intentionally.  Not challenging but there wasn't much depth of flavor or on the nose.  Just not a lot going on here.

Nose: Very subtle, sweet with vanilla and honey and...that's pretty much it.

Taste: High alcohol punch with some wood, vanilla, light sugars, and walnuts.

Finish: Short and spicy with wood notes.

Overall not my favorite.  I'm glad  I tried it so I can "check the box" but I wouldn't go to it again.
Spicy. Carmel, butterscotch, vanilla clove, hits the entire pallet, front to back. Very intense with alcohol on first sip, but after pallet is conditioned, it doesn’t get much better than this one!
almost like a scotch; can taste the smoke after a little water down
Great nose! Orange and floral with caramel undertone. Palette has instant spice and burn that tapers uniquely, finishing with a subtle sweet.
Many bourbons are a little too sweet for my tastes, but this has a woody spice that enlivens it. I find the very dry finish a little odd - really saps the moisture out of my mouth
I only drank it neat, which was probably a mistake. It drinks like its 145 proof. Very sharp. Stings the tongue. I liked it in-store, but wasn’t a fan bringing it home.
Berries and burn. Brown sugar coming through too. Super long finish. Very very good bourbon.

A quality high proof bourbon with a noticeable level of heat and oak. Not as sweet as many Bourbons and has a nice spice kick on the finish. Glad I bought the bottle, but overall I think Wild Turkey Rare Breed is a better pour and is 15 bucks cheaper in SW Michigan.

Old Forester 1920 is up for review tonight.  The mashbill is 72% corn, 18% rye, 10% malted barley.  This one clocks in at 115 proof.  The color on this bourbon is reddish-brown color.  The legs are thin but run very slow. I don’t know the age but by the color you know there are some older barrels that make this one up.  The nose is ethanol, caramel, brown sugar, dark cherries, chocolate, and oak.  The palate is intense caramel and vanilla with the cherry’s and chocolate kind of like chocolate covered cherries, cinnamon spice, with a little alcohol burn but not in a sharp bad way.  The finish is very long and coats your mouth very well with all of the flavors lingering and making you want to take your next sip.
Probably my favorite mainstream bourbon. Holds its own next to bottles costing 2-3 times as much.
Hot with a good burn and sweet finish

Very interesting!  I don't tend to like higher rye mashbills, especially at a higher proof.   But I like this.  There's copious amounts of ethenol on the nose and palate, but it never overwhelmes.  Fruits and cinnamon on both the nose and palate as well.  The finish is perhaps the most unusual aspect to me - I consistently get a long and strong peanut butter note that fades in and out with some vanilla.  There are obviously plenty of other cask strength bourbons out there, but I have yet to try one quite like the 1920

Neat in a rocks glass at Liberty BBQ in Falls Church. Lots of citrus in the nose, followed by rye spice in the taste.  Lingering spice finish.  The word "bright" really comes to mind.  Decent.  7/24/19
1920 is a nice strong bourbon, and does nicely as a one bourbon a night sipper.
I recommend a tiny splash of water to calm the burn and open up the flavor. After that it’s a delicious bourbon. It’s my new favorite. Highly recommended.
Suprising light nose and pallet for a 115 proof bourbon.  The nose is has citrus and nutmeg. Pallet has oak honey. Finish is short but plesent.
Very smooth, drinks like a 90 proof.

A little spice on the nose along with light fruit. 
Light coating on the palate. Definitely gets a tad smokey and oaky. Then finishes with a burn, but it’s good. This was after letting it sit for 10-15 mins due to the higher proof.
I really think this one will open up well as the bottle sits and airs out a little. Adding some water helps as other suggest and surprisingly thickened it up a little.
Slight brown sugar taste notes of tobacco. Good burn.

With just a splash of water or a small ice chip, this opens up to be one of my favorites.  Coates the mouth well and has great complexity.  This absolutely belongs in the same category as Old Forester’s Birthday Bourbon from 2018.  A great value at under $65.  8.7/10

Has the typical Old Forester banana, vanilla, baking spice nose as most Old Foresters do. Lots of corny sweet honey flavor... Made me think of a King's Hawaiian Roll... Immediate high proof burn, gives way to a moderately oily, smooth texture and a toffee & cinnamon finish.

Nose: Sweet dark fruit and brown sugar, some leathery musk, a hint citrus in the effervescent tip of the nose. 

Taste: Cherry, leather, the body (not smoke) of a cigar, nutmeg, cinnamon,  with a long finish that leaves a heat in the front of your mouth.

Experience: it's a lounge in a glass. Cigars, cocktail cherries, and a dancer's kiss, all wrapped in alcohol and leather. 
This is a good one boys, it's a bourbon's bourbon (if that means anything.) 
It should hold up to rocks if you like and should be on the shelf next to EH Taylor, Booker's, and the such.

Nose is some cherry, cinnamon, caramel, oak.

Honey, pecans, almonds, butterscotch, vanilla, tobacco. 

Nose is hot but on the mouth it's velvet
Smooth, typical vanilla, maple notes, great taste with a long burn

Rested 15 minutes. Served neat in a Glencairn. 

Nose - a little spicy. baking spices, black pepper, vanilla, cinnamon. 
Palette - a little heat. Black pepper, cherry. Something else I can’t quite recognize but I really like it. 
Finish - toasted oak, black licorice, the aftertaste of caramel and gingerbread. 

Love this bourbon. Very smooth with a particular taste. Love the higher proof. Would rate it a little higher, but I think the $60 price brings it back down.
I wish I could say it was rated higher given the price point. Similar profile as Woodford at twice the price.
Massive toffee, browned butter, walnuts, date fruit scones.
More notes coming at you than a Rachmaninoff symphony. It's an event drink. Might or might not work as an everyday sipper. Makes the Mitchner's seem drab.
A bit harsher than I expected, but I could really get into this.

Spicy on the palate initially and really warm finish. That great bourbon warmth in the chest. For the high proof quite drinkable. Vanilla comes through. 

McCormacks Whisky Grill
$14 USD per pour
Sweet goodness with a burn. This bourbon is so well balanced it sips like a much lower proof.

This is in my wheel house.
Hefty proof with a beautifully dark color.

Nose is rich and full with brown sugar, dark cherries, oak, and roasty nuts.

Taste is again rich, vanilla, cherry, banana bread & more sweet oak.

Finish is long and smooth, mouth coating with just a touch of Kentucky hug. I get some tongue coating over cooked banana bread in the aftertaste.

Top shelf.

When I choose a bourbon, I like bold flavors and complexity. What I have heard of the Old Forester 1920 Prohibition Style is that it brings both of these things to the table. Today is my birthday, so I decided to treat myself to a bottle. This is the first Old Forester label I have tried, and at 115 proof it is also the highest proof bourbon I have purchased. This taste was a neat pour in a Glencairn glass and I let it breathe for a few minutes before diving in.

I took my first sniff with my nose in the glass and my mouth closed, an amateur move that rewarded me with a punch of ethanol right in the schnoz. When smelling correctly, I was hit by the aroma of rich caramel, dark chocolate, toasted oak, cinnamon, cloves, and a trace of stone fruits. I think of both Christmas and luxury when I inhale these vapors. The palate has heat to be sure, but it is rich and smooth on the tongue. The taste is chocolate forward and is accompanied by cinnamon, vanilla, and notes of bright fruit. There is a smokey, peppery heat as the sip works its way back and down. The medium finish starts hot but quickly mellows into a warm, nutty spice and a lavish smokiness. By the third sip, I am adjusting to the heat and feel that I keep experiencing new flavors while at the same time being certain there is more underneath. Bold and complex is a great way to describe the 1920 and I am excited to see how a splash of water or some ice open this one up. If chocolate and heat are not what you are looking for, stay away from the 1920, but if you are looking for a bourbon that encapsulates the hedonistic and outrageous mood of the Roaring 20s, this is the one for you.
High proof, good flavor and mouthfeel, little harsh. Headache causer.
This is good. Nice oak on it. Think it must be on the older side. Long finish. It has a creamy mouthfeel. Not overly sweet. Good spice. I would buy.
Strong alcohol feel, strong notes of barrel, vanilla, and holiday spices. Syrupy mouth feel and very warm. Very sweet.
Rich sweet and full of life with nice spice.
Sweet vanilla/caramel, allspice, anise, & candied fruit. Warm finish that lingers. Delicious, & sipped neat. 🥃
Flavors are slight and the bite at the end is hard
Really interesting. Heavy spice/smoke/sweet leaving you with a dry mouth. Somehow manages to actually taste old, which is quite fitting.
Very smooth for a 115 proof. Subtle sweetness with a balance heat to finish.
Smooths out over ice, but not super memorable.
Very smooth finish with a hint of vanilla, for a high proof bourbon, this is really good.
A lot going on in this one... need more time

Nose is nice and sweet. 
Tried neat, but finish too bitter  
Added single regular ice cube and it was better at lower temperatures but still hot and with a long bitter finish that gets slightly less bitter over time

At this price point ($55) I'm not sure there's much out there I would consider better.  Like other uncut, unfiltered bourbons the flavors just linger.  The first few sips are spicier with the burn of ethanol.  Tasting again brings more leather and sweater, warmer flavors.  Eventually vanilla shows up with a dance of other flavors that last, and last.  You could pay far more and scour release lines and not find any better.

At long last I grabbed a bottle of this heavyweight bourbon. I love OF Signature 100 so this stuff has a lot to measure up to. Poured neat, deep dark color sets the stage. Swirling it coats the glass like motor oil with thick globby legs. Nose is rich and pungent with melted brown sugar, nutmeg and cinnamon, cooked molasses, caramel apple, hardwood varnish and sweet wood. Complex and powerful. Luscious mouthfeel leads massive palate of creamy dark caramel, candy apple, rye spice, dark chocolate covered cherries and singed graham cracker crust all bolstered by sturdy oak. Great weight and depth. The flavors keep surging and morphing as you ride the wave of 115 proof to long lasting finish of baking and rye spice, raw cinnamon, fading dark toffee/caramel and rich sweet butter and oak . Slightly drying near end to balance out all the sweet notes. Warming sensation from the 115 heat is like a comforting hug. Absolutely fantastic! Easily drinkable neat or add some water to taste. I recently had KC single barrel and Stagg JR, two superb high proof contenders but will take this over both. Its more accessible, smoother and deeper. Bottom line this is one of the best bourbon Ive ever had. Its super rich with perfect sweetness and balance(OF100 on steroids)...........98/100.....cant recommend enough, buy this high octane candy!!!..........damn I love this mashbill!
IMHO, the 1920 is the best of the bunch.

Big bourbon with big flavor - Smokey and perfect amount spice. 

Dark, rich color, even after ice melts. One of my favorites. Love it. Definitely a repeat.

Nose: Intense brown sugar, with all the classic bourbon notes (vanilla, caramel, wood)...but amped up. A nice undertone of leather as well. But the sweet stuff is what steals the show.

Taste: Sugary syrup up front. Spikes with cherry and then rides off with more sugar, char and some banana. Super rich and intense.

Finish: Sticks with you. That banana lingers (giggity), but some rye spice comes through as well. It’s like a peanut butter and banana sandwich.

Overall: This is one of my favorite bourbons regardless of price. Sweet, rich and complete enough to keep you guessing...while still just easy and enjoyable. I love the proof here, it feels perfect. And it’s a great transition bourbon if you’re looking to jump up from the 45% range.

OF1920: 👃 floral melon fruity
Taste - char oak oily Kentucky hug hint of tobacco
Lots of flavor and spice to it.

Smoky oaky palate, finishes with intense spice and a bit of smoke. FWIW this is a good bottle that’s readily available and packs a punch, but is isn’t something I’d seek out again. I expected something a bit more at this proof, but I just get blasted with spice and each aspect of this does not seem faceted enough for the praise this generally gets from most people.
Vanilla, oak, fruit, alcohol on nose, palate to follow with similar notes plus spice, med finish fading with heat, great value.

Medium amber color.  Nose is warm and rich with vanilla, ethanol and slight orange and clove.  Taste is caramel, heat and toasted oak with transition to subtle tobacco, almond and cherry finish that lasts  and dances in the tongue.  Proof isn’t apparent on the tongue and rather than a bite there is a nice b warmth from start to finish.  Pricy but worth keeping on hand - a rival to Bookers for $15 less and also widely available (high is a plus for me)

I’ve been hitting the bourbon a bit more lately because 1) It’s finally fall in Texas (meaning the high is only 80) and 2) Seems like the price of Scotch keeps going up (new tariffs kicking in?...). I’ve always loved Old Forester. I’ve made short work of the classic, the 100, and a few of the single barrels. Been keeping my eye on this one for some time, but I kept my distance because spending more than $40 on bourbon seemed...unnecessary to me with all the quality offerings. 

For a high proof bourbon (it doesn’t say barrel proof, but it must be close) I don’t get that ethanol punch on the nose. Instead I get brown sugar, cherries, and vanilla dialled up to 11. The taste is that classic OF profile. Brown sugar, caramel, and a SUPER oily mouthfeel that results in a very long finish. My favorite part may be the big Kentucky hug at the end. This is definitely a slow sipper, and at $50, it’s a bargain (negating my earlier statement about paying for bourbon). Believe the hype. This one’s a keeper!
Very interesting taste - warm and cinammony on its own, spicy if mixed even with a modicum of water.

Nose: vanilla, corn, heat
Taste: spice, vanilla
Finish: long burn, leather

Nose: Cherry, Vanilla, Some Oak, Ethanol
Taste: Vanilla, Some Smoke, Nuts, Spice. Truly Great Bourbon
Rich mouthfeel, dominating vanilla, buttery, spicy, astringent and hot finish
Tastes like sitting next to a roaring fire at Christmas time with a plate of shortbread cookies. Each sip staving off the snow coming down in big fat flakes just outside the window.
Not a fan.  Strong in the nose.  Not enjoyable
Chocolate and cherry on the back end stood out. Sweet. Definitely hot, but not overwhelmingly so. Big fan. Want it in my cabinet permanently.

The smell is refreshing and bold. I smell fruit notes forsure and honey and hazel nut. The taste is sort of like a gram cracker cinnamon. Fire breaks easily. I could not explain but it was a little spicey.

On the nose there is strong ethanol with notes of brown sugar and cherries. It starts off hot showing it’s proof but provides some vanilla and barrel. The finish is long and strong with the fire fading slowly.

Nose is sweet, caramelized brown sugar, some fruit notes, cinnamon? Almost gingerbread; but not quite.  The palette is bold and full of sweet fruit, caramel, vanilla, some nuttiness.  Nice finish with pepper and lingering warmth.
Strong bite, needs a touch of water to smooth out
Sweet smoke on the nose, instant heat which fades slowly to vanilla, spice, and barrel char. Hotter than I'd prefer neat but opens up very nicely on ice.
Possibly my new favorite bourbon. Sweet, but with just enough Kentucky hug to let you know the oak was good. Absolutely delightful experience from start to finish.
A little sweet and smokey. Could actually taste the vanilla in there.
Sweet but strong. Strong vanilla and rye. Harsh burn neat. Ice opens the vanilla but increases the rye. Solid sipper.

Day 2 of my bourbon advent calendar

Nose: Starts with sweety baking spices like cinnamon, or nutmeg, and a subtle banana note buried behind some oak. Not a whole lot of ethanol for something a little higher on proof

Plate: It starts quite hot and stays hot, but also has slight creamy texture, and the finish is decent.

This is a great affordable option for someone looking into higher proof bourbons. However, this is not my favorite Old Forster expression. I personally love all single barrels from them, but it's still a good go-to for when I'm craving something high proof because it's readily available for me.

Good solid bourbon, but sits at a weird price point. A little too expensive to be a daily drinker but not exceptional enough to be a special bourbon. I guess it’s an every other day drinker!

Caramel, vanilla, and burnt sugar on the nose. Flavor profile is all sweet up front and a slight dry rye at the end. Not terribly complex but not in a bad way. At this price point I’d rather drink blantons which is what this is trying to be and only slightly cheaper.

Stick with the unique 1910
The best old forester I have had, although I have not tried the birthday bourbon.
Cinnamon, spices, woody& dry on the back end

My go-to. 
I get cherries and quite a bit of ethanol on the nose. 
The palate is fairly hot but I get more of a chocolate as opposed to vanilla. The palate to me fades into like I just took a bite of a dark chocolate candy bar.  Great bang for the buck with this one
Love this Bourbon!  Really smooth for a 115 proof.
Delightful nose of vanilla and caramel.  Unbelievably smooth for 115 proof. A solid daily drinker.
Very strong, not bad for my newbie tastes

Very good and highly recommend. I think this one really opens up with a splash of water. Spicy pepper up front. Next cherry and dark chocolate/ cocoa. Followed by the classic KY hug and maybe some ginger.
Sweetly nuanced. Great depth with vanilla, caramel, orange marmalade, and some oiled leather. Great sipper!
This bottle is just nothing special at all. I get no flavors here up front or in the finish.

Finally got to try this tonight in a Glencairn. Very impressed. It's the classic bourbon profile you always want in your cabinet. Sweet (almost maple syrup-y) nose with some heat. Palate is oak and vanilla with the perfect spice/cinnamon Kentucky hug. The finish keeps bringing you back for more. This is one of those whiskeys that's the taste of good memories with family and friends.
Initial strong alcohol on the nose followed by an aroma of vanilla. Taste is spicy and smokey with some hint of vanilla and wood. Medium to long finish, warming down the throat.
Lots of spice up front and a hint of smoke
Best slightly chilled and diluted. Over an ice cube: rich cinnamin and vanilla, but without much sweetness with just a hint of pear.
Sharp flavor. Smooth and drinking with a cigar.
Amazing color. Light nose. Hot on the palate. Slight linger.

Astringent on the nose, as expected at 115 proof. Taste is smooth on the front and middle, with some molasses, brown sugar, and mint throughout. Good burn on the backend that is also typical of a bourbon at this proof. A solid buy and good sipper for a cold winter.
Really sweet nose with surprisingly little alcohol burn considering the proof. Lots of fruit caramel and seemingly little rye spiciness compared to the other of’s I’ve had. Nice warm oaky finish.
Wow! This is a seriously powerful, complex bourbon right here.  So many flavors... Start middle and end change with every sip.

I got sweet sweet sweet on the palate with a nice little cinnamon peppery finish. 
The nose was classic bourbon Carmel vanilla didnt pick up much sweetness of any fruit notes and they translated to the palate not a fruit in sight. It had a very vintage taste to it like sitting out in the wood in fall drinking around a fire. Finish was medium.  Disclaimer tasting notes aren't my thing I just know it was really good

Smell: heat, sweet, warm spice
Taste: heat, sweet corn
Finish: strong finish still delicious

Nose is spicy vanilla and alcohol is coming through. The higher proof is evident the heat comes through more on the front but does come through all the way. A little bit of notes of cherry and vanilla

BACKGROUND: The 1920 expression was the third of four releases in the Old Forester Whiskey Row series of bourbons, which highlights various periods in the Brown-Forman company’s history.

The other Whiskey Row releases include the 1870, which symbolically evokes the original batching process of the first Old Forester bourbon, the 1897, which celebrates the passage of the Bottled In Bond Act, and the 1910, a heavily-oaked bourbon representing a bottling line fire that occurred at the distillery in the early 20th Century.

The 1920 is a “Prohibition Style” whiskey reminiscent of the bourbon being produced at the time the federal Volstead Act was enacted by Congress.  Brown-Forman, the maker of Old Forester, was one of six distilleries licensed to manufacture “medicinal whiskey” that could be purchased with a doctor’s prescription throughout Prohibition.

At 115 Proof, the 1920 has the highest alcohol content of all the offerings in the Whiskey Row series, and that particular proof point is significant in the telling this particular bourbon’s story.

During Prohibition, whiskey was required to be bottled at 100 proof, but to keep from adding too much water to the aged whiskey to proof it down, distillers also barreled whiskey around 100 proof. Brown-Forman estimates that, with “angel’s share” factored in, an aged bourbon of the era would have been about 115 proof out of the barrel.

NOSE: The nose smells strongly of banana, which is typically of many Brown-Forman products, but oak and an underlying scent of citrus are present, as well.

PALATE: The palate tastes completely and EXACTLY like the cordial juice inside a chocolate covered cherry.  The cordial flavor is so dominant that it supersedes anything else.  The oak and caramel, for example, that are typical in most bourbons are rendered completely mute in this one.  It is a sweet and exceptionally tasty palate. 

FINISH: Rye spice and chocolate finally make an appearance on the finish.  The heat from the 115 proof and the palate flavor combine to form a cherry flambe’ that subsides into a distinct after dinner mint flavor.

FINAL ASSESSMENT: I consider myself a student of history, and one of the reasons I jumped feet first into the bourbon hobby was the fascinating stories that abound within its past.  The Whiskey Row series allows me to not only study the history of Brown-Forman and various eras of bourbon production, but to directly experience and taste them, as well.  

While all of the expressions in the Whiskey Row series are enjoyable offerings, the 1920 is a standout that I highly recommend.
Heavy cherry and dark chocolate. Finish is long and fruitful.
Nose is vanilla and caramel. Palate is cherry with vanilla flavor coming through. Finish has cinnamon, with some heat and lasts a little while. Very nice, easy to drink bourbon.

Beautiful copper color, sweet and fruity nose, rich and spicy palate with just a touch of oaky char.

But the finish is where it’s really at. So smooth it almost tricks you into thinking it has no finish...until finally you start to feel that familiar warm tingle growing ever so subtly. The fullness of the 115 proof washes over your mouth like a meandering wave, bringing with it a smokiness that lingers for days.
Oaky cherry cola that just smacked upside me heed

Lovely bourbon this is Old Foresters barrel proof or barrel strength edition. Nose is a cherry bomb like real cherries, with brown sugar, vanilla, apple, cinnamon, light oak, hint of dark chocolate and a touch of alcohol letting you know it's over 110. Taste is not 115 proof tastes like 96 proof maybe 100. The fruit, sweetness, vanilla, brown sugar all jump out on the taste, mid palate you get a little alcohol burn as you also get hit with the rye (mint that shows on the finish), barrel spice and cinnamon. Finish is medium/long with the brown sugar, cinnamon, some oak and the rye induced mint freshness (rinsing with mouthwash) feeling in your mouth lingering the longest.
Banana laffy taffy on the nose
Unique taste. Front end is sweet then heat.
Deep copper color.  Nose of vanilla and cavendish.  Tastes of cherry with sufficient burn to let you know it’s over 100 proof.  Very good sipper.

Received as part of a blind tasting. My notes:


Colour 1.6 - Mahogany, nose has sherry and nuttiness suggesting an Oloroso finish. Palate is a surprise, expected a sherry finished scotch and it feels more like a sweet corn whisky. It is a lovely sipper. A-
91/100. Favorite of the series.  Lots of oak on the nose but the taste is all cherry.  Some rye/clove on the finish.  Some alcohol heat.  Great legs on this.

Nutty Vanilla Coke. Good stuff here. Never had it before and will definitely be
Picking up a bottle
Smooth, a little warm and spicy

Color: copper

Aroma: spicy, multi-grain bread factory

Taste: Cinnamon punches you in the tongue. While you figure that out, it coats the mouth and adds spice cake with frosting.

Finish: you’d think there wouldn’t be much of a finish with as much initial flavor as there was, but there is a slow build to a finish of cinnamon and malty spice heat that lingers in a good way. 

What am I drinking?

Smooth factor: C
Peach and caramel nose. Hot finish.

Nose: dark milky Carmel and maple 
Palate: smooth, rich, spice of cloves, pepper. Woody. 
Finish: Med-long, smooth, as bourbon fades and the spice sits. 
Score: 90/100
Value: good. 54$ paid 
I would keep on shelf.
Great neat, even better with 1 cube

Big burn on the lips. High rye slight sweet. Hints of caramel, honey, vanilla, and toasted oak. A cube doesn’t kill the burn but opens up some sweetness not previously there. For the price and ABV you can do better.

Noses sweet, vanilla and candy corn, hits the palate sweet with caramel notes, toasted marshmallow and some sweet oakiness and lingering heat to finish. Really a great bourbon for after dinner as a dessert, added a few drops of water to open up the sweetness.
my favorite everyday drink.  great proof without overwhelming.  lots of dark cherry,  nuttiness, caramel dream. i'll always have this in my collection
For a 115 proof whiskey this is surprisingly easy drinking.  Very sweet with a lingering spicy finish. Stands up very well to ice.
Amazing nose to it, even with the 120 proof it is an easy pour to drink.

Nose... Candied caramel, raisins, apricots, and a strong scent of freshly baked rye bread bordering on french toast...

Color... A light to medium copper...

Taste... Marshmallow, apricot, butter, almond, mint, and a floral yet herbal quality. The taste is ever evolving with this bottle.

Overall... It's quite a nice value for the complexity it offers. So many bold and nuanced flavors. This bottle has legs for days plus a smooth and buttery mouth feel. Very solid indeed....
Leather and butterscotch nose. Complex flavor; some brown sugar, but haven’t fully figured it out. Hot, lingering finish. Definitely a more advanced profile.
Way better than I thought it would be after 1910.

For 100th review, (whose counting), the bottle of "prohibition" style whiskey jumped out at me.   There are certain bottles you can open and get a feeling of stepping into the past, maybe something your great granddad would have sampled.  Bottles like Jim Beam Repeal Batch, or just Gold Label(BiB), Old Granddad hi-test, a few others and now Old Forester enters the fray with an advertised "antique" style whiskey.

No pun intended, this one is full of spirit.  A formidable body of aromas rise in the nose, perhaps a citrus punch, hints of marzipan and certainly musty barn wood.  Sweet corn spirits in caramel and cinnamon spice make this a promising venture. 

This one front loads on the palate with a powerful punch of heat and spice, probably thanks to the substantial proof, the flavors swim and dance before the shear alcohol content breaks it all down.   A leather graininess and some sort of bitters, cherry bark maybe. Not much of a finish as it evaporates right out of your throat but while it lasts you have a delicious sample of all those nose notes to behold.    

The alcohol flash and bitter finish keep the palate dry and ready for subsequent sips,  proving the adage "old" whiskey's are for sipping.  The 1920 has gotten its fair share of press and blather from the whiskey channels lately along with enough paper-gold medals and certainly some of that is warranted while some is just hype.  There is definitely something for a whiskey drinker to like here as this one may fall into the classification of a "whiskey drinkers" whiskey.  Either way Morris certainly is on to something with his Prohibition style offering.  Cheers!
Warm in the mouth and going down. Maybe a little more than i prefer. Nice after taste. Smells yummy!

This old Forester prohihibition 1920 is crazy good. It is complex and has ton going on but all of it blends perfectly. Maple syrup, Apple, vanilla and orange on the nose. Then nutty, Graham cracker, malty goodness taste. The finish is slightly peppery, with a little honey toast and smoke on the finish.
Oh how I missed ye. Such great BF flavor, maybe the tips.

Nose: banana, brown sugar
Taste: chocolate, nutty, slight ethanol
Spice and alcohol fades into a good chew and warm hug.  Nice buttery aftertaste.  Thin sweetness reminiscent of butter scotch on the front end.

There's something about this thats simply enjoyable and better than the sum of its parts.  As the graph says, lots of flavor peaks that go well together.  It took about 3-4 bottles where I couldn't keep this bourbon on the shelf in my liquor cabinet for me to realize that this is one of my go-to favorites.  Flavor wins over snob value.

N - 90: Spices, cinnamon, nutmeg. Faint alcohol notes.

T - 86: Very high and sweet. Slightly difficult to drink due to high proof.

F - 87: Medium to long finish. The taste slowly ramps up even after tasting. No oak bitterness. Gives a nice clean mouth feel.

87.66/100
Strong at first but leaves a vanilla pepper aftertaste that is actually quite pleasant. Adding ice allows water to enter the drink slowly changing the profile as you sip.
Nice nose. I smell “woods” and spice. Taste is spicy as well. Finish is warm.
I really enjoy this. It is slightly different that what I’m used to, it has a sweeter taste and a slightly different mouth feel. It’s a bit hot, but has a full flavor.
Very spicy and smoky with hints for orange zest. One of my favorites
This will go head to head with Elijah Craig Barrel Proof B519.  This is 115 proof vs 122.2 proof on Elijah.  This seams more smooth and rich in flavors.  For the price this is in my top 10 for sure!
Sweet oak nose, strong burn, mellow finish

After trying four Old Forester products in the last 6 months I've concluded Distiller Expert Reviewers have a grudge against this product line. It's quickly become one of my favorite American whiskey brands. Almost always available at my local ABCs, this is an excellent high proof bourbon buy. I purchased this before Christmas with my brother and split the bottle putting my half into a Jack Daniel's SiB 375 mL (also split a Pikesville Rye).

The nose is very sweet without too much oak or ethanol punch. It is primarily berries/cherries with chocolate notes, combined with brown sugar/caramel with oak notes if you inhale deeply. Notably absent, the strong banana note I've gotten with most Brown-Forman products. There is a hint but it has faded over the months I've had it open.

It goes down so smooth. I know it's been open for 3 months but it was excellent upon cracking the bottle. Initially the fruit notes are present but they disappear, with mostly syrup and oak on the taste and finish. The oak spice and/or ethanol are most present on the finish. It is long, lingering for 10-20 seconds. 

My brother, who's more into scotch and rye and not as adventurous with high proof bourbons said this was one of his favorite bourbons to date. I highly recommend the 1920 if you're into the denser, sweeter bourbons with low rye spice. It's easily one of my favorites.
Mint and oak on the nose, complex pallet with the same mint and oak and strong spice, smooth and tasty with burn. Solid bourbon
Great bourbon for the higher proof. Smooth with a lot of flavor. Definitely worth a try.

Carmel and vanilla on the palette. I keep coming back to this one. Sampled it with Blanton’s single barrel which is very good but there is something about old Forster 1920 115 proof. I expected a substantial burn for this proof, but it s surprisingly smoooooth.
Heavy caramel and oak on the nose. Well balanced with sweet and spice. Strong fish that gets sweet on the end. Very well balanced pour.
My favorite Old Forester for sipping!
Smooth leather, surprisingly little burn for the proof

I hear that others have compared this to Elijah Craig Barrel Proof and although this is very good, it's not better than ECBP... especially C919.  I feel that it needs a little more time to open up, however, and then it's  very good.
Bottle has been open for 5 months now and opened up nicely.

향 : 깊게 들이마셔도 강하지 않은 아세톤, 그속에 옅은 플로랄, 신선한 오크, 설탕
맛 : 꽤 스파이시, 핫, 쌉쌀스모키, 안녕 난 가죽맛이야!!
피니쉬 : 웜, 쓴맛이 뒤로 쭉 빠짐

워터드롭 후 
강한 향이 싹 빠짐, 쌉쌀한 오크맛이 강하게 올라옴

1시간 에어링후
드디어 체리마루 향이 느껴짐, 도수대비 매우 부드럽고 짧은 피니쉬

Very smooth for the proof. Wish I knew more about the distilling process to better understand the consistent smoothness of all OF product. There’s enough complexity to keep you coming back and with a medium finish this is a very fun Bourbon without a doubt. Grab a bottle of 1910 and experiment with your own 1915 blend. Sorry, mingle.

Color: a fantastic copper gold, looks beautiful in a crystal glass.

Legs: slow to develop and trickle ever so softly and spaced fairly well.

Nose: first sniff, boom punch right in the nostril. There's that 115 proof. The next set of nose dives are more calm with vanilla caramel oak and hints of butter and toffee.

Body: more vanilla and caramel than I was expecting and not as much bite as I was expecting from a 115.  

Finish: slight burn on the end with some complex flavor appearing. Some hints of cherry or other fruit. 

Not rough where it takes your breath away but maybe one to let open up with a touch of distilled water.

Will be custom aging a bottle of 1910 with a bottle of 1920 to balance out the sweet and spicy, looking to do that in a 1L barrel for 8 months.  Can't wait to taste that result.
A lot of dark cherry character. Good amount of heat but not overkill
Loved this, was so flavorful you don't even realize it is 115 proof
fantastic bourbon..great flavors and nice long finish
Initial heat with vanilla, toffee, caramel, dusty corn, and baking spice. Short dry finish, I get dry corn bread.

Have heard great things about this bourbon and was hoping I wasn’t going to be let down. I wasn’t. 

Nose is traditional light fruits with a slight hints of tobacco, vanilla chocolate, molasses and maple syrup. Cherry syrup. Hints of cotton candy after tasting Weller at one point. Take a sip then boom! Such a full bodied bourbon. 

Long finish though slightly metallic and waxy on the back end. 

Would highly recommend. 

I use the rating scale below. Distiller uses a scale of 5 and I use a scale of 10, but I’m sure you’re not too drunk to do the math! 

1. Disgusting - So bad I poured it out.
2. Poor - I wouldn't consume by choice.
3. Bad - Multiple flaws.
4. Below average - Not bad, but many things I'd rather have.
5. Good - Just average.
6. Very Good - Better than average.
7. Great - Well above average.
8. Excellent - In a league of its own.
9. Incredible - An all-time favorite.
10. Perfect
Aroma - Dark Fruit and Spice / Taste - Peppercorn and Maple / Finish - Spice
Spiced cherry, boozy nose.  Cinnamon, nutmeg and pepper move to a smoky, burnt chocolate warm finish.
It’s 115 proof, so strong, lots of heat and initial burn, but has nice spice, cinnamon, caramel richness. For hard core bourbon enthusiasts, you will not be disappointed. Not for beginners.
It’s everything I want in a bourbon.  It’s high proof and full of flavor.  Best part is you can actually walk into a store and buy it. Crazy right

Nose - Caramel, vanilla, cherry, brown sugar and oak, and almost no alcohol vapor.
Taste - Gingersnap cookies, marshmallows, dark chocolate, a small amount of spice burn.
Finish - Medium-to-long. Lingering brown sugar taste with a hint of oak spice.

It smells like maple syrup and pancakes. The taste is thick and chewy, and reminds me of Christmas cookies. It is 115 proof and it does not taste like it. It isn't entirely smooth but it is incredibly balanced with a wall of different flavors. Adding a dash of water helps bring out additional marshmallow sweetness.

This is a surprising whiskey. I read fantastic things about it and I was expecting it to be all hype, but I could not have been more wrong. It is a complex, delicious bourbon with just the right amount of kick.

I was surprised to see the Distiller expert score for this is only 85. The scores are subjective, but they have no credibility with me when Evan Williams Single Barrel bourbon is sitting at 96. If you enjoy bourbon then try this whiskey. You will not be disappointed.

This may be the best bourbon I've tasted by a mile... when taking into account the value. The nose lets you know the proof, while being layered, but I feel the flavor is kaleidoscopic. There are definitely dark red fruits in the taste. The savory peanut butter note shows up in the mid-range for me...I'm probably made of 60% peanut butter if you subscribe to the "you are what you eat philosophy." With a little water, this peanut butter note turns into a mild banana-nut bread. The finish fades out into a bitterness that makes me want to drink more. It is very easy to drink more despite the high proof, making it a dangerous but sexy pour. New staple for the cabinet.

Aroma - Toasted Oak, Cherry Garcia Ice Cream
Flavor - Cinnamon, Buttery Caramel, Marshmallow
Finish - Med-Long Oak Char, Black Pepper and Toffee
Absolutely delicious. Thick and rich maple syrup flavor and viscosity. Does not drink like a 115 at all, very smooth little burn.

nose - light at first spicy lingering. Oak notes. 
Taste - hot, smoky, Carmel and vanilla, smoked walnuts
Finish - medium heat, dry, and spicy warmth. 
I love the smoky and charred taste and finish and enjoy the higher proof of this one over the 1910.
bitter, nutty after taste, a little burn going down
Smells great, taste is smooth and sweet with some peanut in it? Finish reflects the proof but is not overly harsh. Really good.
Hot, which I guess is the cinnamon notes. Different flavors the more I sip. Great sweet nose. Good find when you can find it

Hot on the nose with some spices, dark fruits, tobacco, and dark chocolate. The palate was pretty disappointing for me. There are so many different flavors here, but I thought they clashed more than anything. For me this was pretty hot, even for a 115 proof, and none of the flavors really stood out against the heat. It mellowed out with a few drops of water, but even then I didn't think it was particularly good. It basically tasted like a spicier version of the 100-Proof OF, with more cherry & black pepper, and a little less banana & vanilla. 

It's definitely worth trying and I'm glad I gave it a shot, but I will not buy it again at $55-60 personally. For higher-proof options, I think Knob Creek's Single Barrel picks are a much better buy. The ones I've tasted have a similar flavor profile to the 1920, but were much more well-rounded, and $10-15 less expensive.
Strong but sweet at the end. Very good!

I'm used to higher proofs like bookers and other barrel proofs that are better at hiding their proof on the nose which this one wasn't great at hiding but, still able to get some nice caramel and vanilla on the nose. The taste was caramel red apple and the finish was long with a caramelized charred barrel.

OldFo 1920

*NOSE: Fruit Cocktail in Syrup, the kind with extra Cherries. Burnt Brown Sugar. Freshly opened pouch of Chewing Tobacco. Raw Almonds. Varnished Oak. A Light Floral note comes and goes. Tread lightly or get admonished with a big hit of Heat.
*NEAT: Cherry. Deep Vanilla. Oak. Black Pepper heat. Pretty Basic. Just a tick on the Astringent Side, but not so much it's an issue. Thick Clingy finish with a BIG Kentucky Hug blooming in the chest. Cinnamon, Cherry and Oak layer on the palate with each sip.
*SPLASH: Nose gets Gooey, Sticky Caramel. The Palate gains some much needed complexity with Chocolate, Coffee, Sweet Cream and Hazelnut notes. A little added Barrel Char. The finish becomes Super Sweet. Fittingly the empty glass smells just like a Milky Way wrapper.

*VERDICT: I finally decided to review something from the Whiskey Row Series. I have a bottle of 1910 that I just can't make up my mind about ,so I haven't put pen to paper on it yet. I really enjoyed this. Pretty basic when consumed Neat, but man do a few drops of water open this one up. I see lots of people who are making "1915" by mixing this with the 1910, and I can definitely see how that would be a worthwhile experiment. I wish that I liked the Old Forester profile better, but I applaud everyone involved in this series for experimenting with batching, barrel placement, entry proofs, etc. to create unique bottlings. This just edges out the Rye as my favorite OldFo so far.
Smooth and strong drink. Palate is caramel, apple, cinnamon, full. Enjoyed neat - great alone or pairs well with many cigars due to being so well balanced.

Newer to bourbon but sorry to say I didn’t enjoy this as much as I’d hoped. I got burnt caramel and vanilla, which was nice, but I didn’t enjoy the pepper and spice I got on the back end. Still like Buffalo Trace and Blanton’s single barrel more.
I am tasting huge notes of banana and caramel.  If you don’t think it’s smells like a banana foster than you’re fired!! Lol.  Love this bourbon
It’s highly praised but I don’t find it that enjoyable. A lot better bourbons for less money

Massively flavorful and bold.  Ton of spice & smoke, fading in a very dry caramel apple finish. 
The ethanol hit on this one is substantial, but ice can smooth it out and bring out the caramel and vinila more which can otherwise be overpowered.
Lots of flavor, Carmel. Lots of burn, high ABV. Need ice. At $50-$60 I don’t see the value
A bit harsh on the first sip but smoothes out nicely.

Nose: Vanilla, cinnamon, caramel
Neat: Hot, good tingle/burn going down; vanilla and caramel with strong ethanol 
Rocks: Vanilla and cinnamon 

Up there with Elijah Craig Barrel Proof as one of my favorite high proofs.
A lot of sweetness up front. Very warm and a spicy. Lots of grain flavors. Vanilla on the back end with more sweetness.

You really need to take your time with this one. If you judge this whiskey on just a couple of tastings you're giving this whiskey the short shift. If you give this whiskey a chance it really comes through as a really great sipper. The nose on this one is great, something I personally wouldn't mind wearing as a fragrance. As you smell the rich cherry and wood you want to explore it deeper, but as you try and take a bigger whiff, your nose gets burnt as  you're reminded of that high proof. As for the taste you're hit with a rich, complex mouth feel that leaves your mouth a sharp sweetness and a nice burn of alcohol that fades into a woody after taste. This one is in the $60 range out here in LA, its a little pricey but I'm not sorry I bought it. Its a nice one to have in your collection.
Sweet aroma, fishing is dark berry, and oak. Superb
